title: 1920s geomectric-tendency Art Deco high-contrast display sans
content:
I like this. Art Deco, but with a suggestion of the International Style geometricism that's about to replace it. Plus: Love the U and the R. (Not so much the S) Any ideas? Digital versions?

Source: [http://tsutpen.blogspot.se/2013/08/and-then-it-was-ephemera-84.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726/http:/tsutpen.blogspot.se/2013/08/and-then-it-was-ephemera-84.html "http://tsutpen.blogspot.se/2013/08/and-then-it-was-ephemera-84.html")

Font: 

 Ultra Modern 

Solved By: 

 [Atwe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726/http:/typophile.com/user/45414 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [1929.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726/http:/typophile.com/files/1929.jpg) | 126.76 KB |
author: Birdseeding

comments.content: Ultra Modern, designed by Douglas C. McMurtrie in 1928 for Ludlow.

Excellent! Thank you. Base on that knowledge, two very different digital versions: [http://www.myfonts.com/person/Douglas\_C\_McMurtrie/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726/http:/www.myfonts.com/person/Douglas_C_McMurtrie/ "http://www.myfonts.com/person/Douglas\_C\_McMurtrie/") Pity they both lack the graceful stricture of the metal type. :)

SG & RR digitizations both acceptable in my opinion. If you prefer a more hairline effect go for the RR. If you prefer less contrast go for SG.  
To compare with original check the [Ludlow Typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726/http:/archive.org/details/LudlowTypefacesEditionD1140) book at archive.org. Ultra Modern regular and bold is at pages 166 to 169. Note that Ludlow also produced an italic.  
Don

Here is a sample from the Ludlow Typefaces book that you can use to compare with the SG & RR digitizations.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414065726im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UltraModernInUse@Ludlow187p167detail_3569.jpg)
  
Don
